references: In TableÂ 1, we provide the quantitative comparisons on Office-Caltech10 and DomainNet datasets with the presence of domain shifts across clients. Our approach achieved the highest 96.81% and 71.64% average accuracies on Office-Caltech10 and DomainNet, respectively, as shown from TableÂ 1. Furthermore, our method demonstrated the best communication efficiency, using only approximately 0.01% of parameters in comparison to other existing pFL methods. Note that the costs of FedRepÂ [8] and FedBABUÂ [37] are the numbers of model parameters of the ViT backbone (i.e., 85.8M), while the communication costs ofÂ [34, 14, 4] can be approximated to 85.8M, as they transmit the ViT backbone along with a single-layer classifier, which adds relatively few parameters.

In addition to domain discrepancy, we conducted comparisons on the imbalanced class distribution scenario using CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets, as shown in TableÂ 2.
As mentioned in Sec.Â 4.1.2, two types of imbalanced data are simulated, including disjoint label space and imbalanced label distribution drawn from Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(0.1)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ0.1Dir(0.1).
TableÂ 2 demonstrates that our method performed favorably against existing FL works over the two datasets on both types of label imbalance.
To further exhibit the ability of our method to more practical scenarios, we compare with state-of-the-art works for the cross-site medical image diagnosis task using Dermoscopic-FL. As we can observe in TableÂ 3, our pFedPG consistently performed superiorly against other FL methods on all hospital sites.

S4.T4.caption: Table 4: Analysis of our personalized prompt generation and the architecture of prompt generator GğºG on benchmark datasets.
S4.T4.table:
Module Method Office-Caltech10 DomainNet CIFAR-10 CIFAR-100
Prompt generation FedVPT 94.29 64.16 89.39 55.49
Pbâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹esubscriptPğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘’\textbf{P}_{base} 93.16 64.87 88.23 66.89
Architecture of GğºG MLPÂ [44] 94.96 63.33 87.47 66.73
AdaINÂ [20] 95.72 70.08 89.77 69.44
pFedPG 96.81 71.64 90.08 70.96
references:
In the upper part of TableÂ 4, we intend to verify the effectiveness of our personalized prompt generation for facilitating adaptation at each client on benchmark datasets, where CIFAR-10/100 are under the setting of disjoint label space. In TableÂ 4, we first ablate PnsubscriptPğ‘›\textbf{P}_{n} with the global prompts obtained by global averaging (as in FedVPT).
As reported in TableÂ 4, the globally averaged prompts cannot achieve satisfactory performance since sharing a single set of prompts would not be favorable to heterogeneous clients.
In addition, we examine the performance of applying the trained client-agnostic prompt basis Pbâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹esubscriptPğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘’\textbf{P}_{base} to clients instead of applying personalized prompts PnsubscriptPğ‘›\textbf{P}_{n}.
We observed that the performance of Pbâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹esubscriptPğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘’\textbf{P}_{base} is still inferior to ours (which applies PnsubscriptPğ‘›\textbf{P}_{n}).
As evident from the above experiments, the effectiveness of our proposed personalized prompt generation for allowing personalized FL under various types of data heterogeneity would be successfully verified.

From the results shown in the lower half of TableÂ 4, we see that the performance dropped when we replaced our cross-attention-based prompt generator GğºG and Pbâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹esubscriptPğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘’\textbf{P}_{base} with an MLP-based network asÂ [44], which acts on client descriptors and then output prompts for each client.
The inferior performance of the MLP-based prompt generator is due to its high training complexity and instability, resulting from the requirement of deploying a fully-connected layer for each prompt embedding. Another alternative prompt generator is to compute adaptive instance normalization (AdaIN)Â [20] for Pbâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹esubscriptPğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘’\textbf{P}_{base} and the client descriptor dnsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›d_{n}. This method allows for the transfer of client-agnostic prompts Pbâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹esubscriptPğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘’\textbf{P}_{base} to personalized prompts PnsubscriptPğ‘›\textbf{P}_{n} by replacing the mean and variance calculated from the client descriptor dnsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›d_{n}, similar to the style transfer approachÂ [20]. However, as seen in TableÂ 4, directly computing AdaIN did not explicitly model the prompt generation process, resulting in inferior performance compared to ours.
The results summarized in TableÂ 4 confirm the effectiveness of our designed architecture of prompt generator GğºG.

S4.T5.table:
Kğ¾K Office-Caltech10 DomainNet CIFAR-10 CIFAR-100

references:
We also analyze the impact of the number of prompts Kğ¾K on benchmark datasets, and show the results in TableÂ 5.
We found that when the number of prompts is set too low (e.g., K=1ğ¾1K=1), the modelâ€™s accuracy drops slightly due to insufficient capacity. In contrast, if the number of prompts is set too high, such as 100 or 200, the modelâ€™s performance significantly degrades. This is because a large number of prompts may encode noisy and task-irrelevant information, which can adversely affect the quality of the features derived from foundation models.
With the above observation, we thus set Kğ¾K as 10 for these datasets which achieves the best trade-off between communication cost and performance.
